summary: 186 patients, including 36 deaths, had been diagnosed with MERS-coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infection. median age of the patients was 55 years (range, 16 to 86) a total of 55.4% of the patients had one or more coexisting medical conditions. the world health organization has been notified of 1,638 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 587 fatal cases, in 26 countries as of February 26th, 2016. these confirmed cases have been directly or indirectly linked to countries in the Arabian Peninsula. primary MERS-CoV infections are presumably associated with community zoonotic exposure and may be passed to family members via limited secondary transmission. retrospective observational study focused on clinical characteristics of confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection in the Republic of Korea. all patients with laboratory-confirmed MERS-CoV infection were identified during the outbreak in the Republic of Korea. confirmatory tests were performed only for suspected cases. rRT-PCR tests targeted the upstream E protein (UP-E) and open reading frame 1a gene segments of MERS-CoV. a major means of obtaining data was review of medical records, including doctors' and nurses' charts, imaging findings, and laboratory results. fever AND pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (based on clinical or radiologic evidence) AND either a history of travel from countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula within 14 days before symptom onset. Fever AND symptoms of respiratory illness (e.g. cough, shortness of breath) and presence in a healthcare facility (as a patient, worker, or visitor) within 14 days before symptom onset in a country in or near the Arabian Peninsula. Statistical analysis Collected data were categorized with respect to demographics, clinical symptoms, comorbidities, laboratory test results, image findings, treatments performed, and clinical outcomes. statistical analysis Collected data were categorized with respect to demographics, clinical symptoms, comorbidities, laboratory test results, and image findings. 52.2% of the patients were 55 years of age or older. hypertension, diabetes, and solid organ malignancy were the most common coexisting medical conditions. a total of 55.4% of the patients had one or more coexisting medical conditions. 103 patients underwent urinalysis, 44(42.7%) had proteinuria and 36(35.0%) had hematuria. compared with survivors, the deceased more frequently exhibited leucocytosis, hypoalbuminaemia, elevated serum creatinine and CRP levels, and hypoxemia. seven (3.8%) patients were treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. a total of 38 (20.4%) died in hospitals from the day of symptom. the median interval from symptom onset to death was 14 days (range, 1–174 days) two patients (1.1%) died before confirmation of MERS. the median interval from symptom onset to discharge was 21 days (range, 7–187 days), the median duration of fever was 8 days (range, 0–54 days) and the median time to a negative conversion of virus as determined via rRT-PCR analysis of sputum was 17 days (range, 4–45 days). 55 years 8.63 (3.19-23.30) 0.01 Symptoms during the entire disease course Dyspnea 18.81 (2.39-148.41) 0.01 Coexisting medical condition Diabetes mellitus 2.47 (1.06-5.72) 0.04 Chronic lung disease 2.24 (1.04-4.79) 0.04 Vital sign at admission Systolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg 5.38 (1.65-17.49) 0.01 Laboratory abnormalities at admission White blood cell count >10,000 /mm a - no. hypertension, diabetes, and solid organ malignancy were the most common coexisting medical conditions. a total of 55.4% of the patients had one or more coexisting medical conditions. four patients underwent arterial blood gas analysis, which revealed a decreased PaO2:FiO2 ratio (300) in 56.8% of patients. the deceased more frequently exhibited leucocytosis, hypoalbuminaemia, elevated serum creatinine and CRP levels, and hypoxemia. acute respiratory distress syndrome, acute kidney injury, and shock occurred in 20.7%, 14.0%, and 13.4% of patients. from the day of symptom onset, seven patients (3.8%) died within 7 days and 33 (17.7%) died within 28 days. symptom onset to discharge was 21 days (range, 7–187 days), the median duration of fever was 8 days (range, 0–54 days), and the median time to a negative conversion of virus was 17 days (range, 4–45 days). risk factors for death from MERS In univariate analysis, the deceased were older than the survivors (median age, 69 vs. 51 years), and included a smaller portion of HCWs than did the survivors (2.8 vs. 25. disease 2.24 (1.04-4.79) 0.04 Vital sign at admission Systolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg 5.38 (1.65-17.49) 0.01 Laboratory abnormalities at admission White blood cell count >10,000 /mm3 3.16 (1.10-9.07) 0.03 Treatment Mechanical ventilation 8.04 (2.95-21.92) 0.01 aIn Cox-regression analysis, the data was censored at September 30, 2015 for survivors. this is the largest report of an outbreak outside of the Middle East. this is the largest report of an outbreak outside of the Middle East. 186 MERS patients in the Republic of Korea from May through September 2015. asymptomatic patients were rare in this outbreak, presumably because confirmatory MERS-CoV tests were performed only for symptomatic patients. in a previous outbreak in jeddah, 25.1% of laboratory-confirmed cases were reported to have been asymptomatic. 80% of those who were reached by telephone had experienced at least one symptom [4]. .5% of patients, although clinical decisions for their use were made by attending physicians, not by researchers. we were not able to assess the clinical impact of antiviral therapy on outcomes as most patients with severe pneumonia received combination antiviral therapy along with comprehensive supportive care. clinical features did not differ significantly from those of previous outbreaks in the Middle East. overall mortality rate was 20.4%, which was lower than that reported in other countries.
